body: @granders probably not since we have benchmarked that branch in the past and aren't adding much new code to it. Thanks.

@hachikuji Could you please take a look at this when you get a chance? The patch for [KAFKA-3853](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3853) is kind of related to this, and I'd like this to be finalized and merged first. Thanks.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.0, thanks @fhussonnois !
@ewencp @hachikuji I added a unit test. Can you take another look?
LGTM. Merged to trunk.
@ijuma The PR was updated. I hope it addresses your concerns. Thanks.
Unit test passed locally. LGTM and merged to both trunk and 0.10.0 branch. Thanks @mfenniak !

One minor comment and otherwise LGTM.

Great cleaning up the unit tests as well!
Thanks @guozhangwang - comment fixed.
Left a few more comments, also I did not see `TopologyBuilder`'s toString function as @theduderog suggested?
Merged to trunk.
@guozhangwang @norwood @theduderog - as discussed. Please take a look. Note: we don't currently limit memory usage, so that will be added once KIP-63 is done.

@johnhofman Only gave it a quick once over, but can I suggest a possible alternative implementation? `SchemaBuilder` intentionally implements the `Schema` interface. Could we just make the `build()` method handle resolving any `SchemaBuilders` into their final `Schemas`? We pass in unmodifiable maps, but that isn't strictly required (it's just to add some level of protection to the schemas), so I think you could generate the output structure and then patch things up if there are any references to `SchemaBuilders` in there.
@guozhangwang @ewencp
Merged to trunk.
@hachikuji This in another pending PR that conflicts with changes required for [KAFKA-3853](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3853), and would be great if we can finalize it soon. Thanks.

@ijuma LGTM. One thought I had is whether we should move `TopicConstants` into the server code since it seems like the intent is for the client to only depend on the internal topics returned from the metadata API. What do you think?
@hachikuji Yeah, it's a fair point about moving it into the server code. I thought of that too, but was being conservative. I can do it if you think that we should.
@ijuma No strong preference either way, but that would make the intention a little clearer.
@ijuma I am +1 on merging this. current behavior doesn't sound right.

@harshach, I am suggesting that the approach in KAFKA-3396 is the right one for trunk. The broker won't populate unauthorized topics for topics that the user doesn't have Describe permissions for. With that change, this change doesn't seem to make sense.

The change here could be OK for the 0.10.0 branch though as it's more conservative.

Thank you for the cleanup, @ijuma. Code looks way better now.
Especially appreciate finding zkUtils.close() and the unused variable in reassignment check. 

LGTM
Anything else I have to do to get this merged?

@13h3r, I think it would be nice to have a test that exercised the consumer to complement the `SubscriptionState` unit test (to make it less likely that we break this again if we refactor things). Also, it seems like the PR description is just restating the PR title, I would edit it and make it blank if there's nothing else to add (the PR description becomes the merged commit message so that's why we care).
LGTM
LGTM
Yes, I meant within the project itself. One way to check if GZipInputStream is closed is to call `read` which throws an IOException if the stream is closed.
Review by @gwenshap
Tests passed locally.

@ijuma the compressor isn't exposed by the iterator. I can expose that, but it feels like the classic "should we/shouldn't we" thing about private members. Seeing as I'm new to the codebase, I'd love your take on that.
@guozhangwang @dguy please have a look. Thanks.
Couple of minor things, but otherwise LGTM
Haven't done the `TopologyBuilder` part yet, next commit. Stay tuned.

@ijuma LGTM to fix the immediate issue. But using this fix means we'll never migrate old message formats. Is the expectation that this is just a temporary fix and longer term we'll figure out a better strategy for rewriting the message format? If clients are ever going to be able to retire old log message formats (admittedly, probably not necessary for quite a long time), it seems like we'll eventually need to be able to reformat compacted topics that people might want to use for source of truth data.

Also, while extremely unusual, its worth pointing out that compression algorithms _can_ sometimes result in larger data even if you remove some data from the input. I'd expect this is rare enough not to be a problem, but it's not strictly guaranteed that if you compact a segment and recompress that the compressed version will be smaller or the same size as the original.

Thanks for the review @ewencp. Yes, the plan is to come up with a better longer term fix in the future. It will probably involve changing consumers so that they can handle oversized messages (i.e. sticking to max message becomes an optimisation instead of a correctness issue). For now, if there is a retention strategy enabled, that helps people move away from the old format.

It's a fair point about compression algorithms guarantees with regards to data size. This change doesn't fix that, but doesn't make it worse. We'll tackle that in the future too.
Tested this patch on tweaked SimpleBench with 10 threads, and have observed that the locking contention overhead is largely reduced. Ping for reviews again @ijuma @miguno @gfodor
I have encountered the case where after-compression size is larger, when you are only compressing one or two records as a batch. I think it is so rare that we did not investing in fixing it yet.

maybe not in this pr, but i think it would be good to eventually get this abstracted for any store type. e.g. if you have a mixture of rocks/inmemory stores you may want to be able to change the inmemory maxentries in a similar way.

@guozhangwang @theduderog I looked into the TopologyBuilder and decided not to provide a toString for that after some thinking. There is a lot of processing required to process the entire graph in TopologyBuilder, and by the time you've done that, it's basically the same output as ProcessorTopology. So I'll stop here.

Thanks, @enothereska.  This is a good start.  At some point, we may want to support a way to get this data in machine readable format (say JSON) to be able to support visualizations like [this](https://databricks.com/blog/2015/06/22/understanding-your-spark-application-through-visualization.html).  Beyond the scope of this PR but something to think about.
Merged to trunk, and piggy-backed to 0.10.0 with some conflicts resolved.

@norwood i think eventually you'll be able to supply your own custom built StoreSupplier via the DSL. So you'd be able to build to provide whatever settings you like to the InMemory or other store. The issue with Abstracting it is that what do you abstract it to? Config of an InMemory store is vastly different to an RocksDB store which will be vastly different to some Custom stores.
Minor comment about unit test, otherwise LGTM.
LGTM

But I'll take a harder look tomorrow and see if I can figure out why that test failed.
It's probably unrelated to your PR.
Thanks for the PR, merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
I ran this branch on Confluent Jenkins a number of times and there were no timing-related failures. If either of the committers in this thread gives me a LGTM, I will merge it.
@hachikuji  Thanks for the thorough feedback. I hope I addressed all of them in the recent update.
@granders this looks good to you? I confirmed ducktape can collect this test. Thanks.
@ijuma Thanks for the advise. Consumer test implemented.

Thanks @enothereska, I've confirmed that ducktape can collect and run this now, this looks good to me.

This observation doesn't have to affect this patch, but I just noticed when running this that data is returned as a single string which is almost, but not quite, parseable as json. If you return it as a dict, it will be dumped as a json object, and easier for future tools to pick this up and aggregate.

E.g.

```
    def collect_data(self, node):
        # Collect the data and return it to the framework
        output = node.account.ssh_capture("grep Performance %s" % self.STDOUT_FILE)

        data = {}
        for line in output:
            parts = line.split(':')
            data[parts[0]] = float(parts[1])
        return data
```
AFAICT there are no direct tests/validations included in this PR, right?
@guozhangwang Thanks. Can you please share more details on "locking contention overhead is largely reduced"? What metrics improved and by how much?
+1 to what @ijuma said.  It's a bit hard to judge the improvement of this PR if we don't have a meaningful before-after comparison.
@hachikuji Moved the internal topics definition to the server. Tests passed locally.
Thanks @granders . I adjusted the json printing as you suggested, good catch.

@guozhangwang it prints the node itself first, then the children. So it will print the sink node (see below), but won't look for it's children.

```
KafkaStreams processID:a35956ee-91ee-4e6a-9005-8d93bac82210
    StreamsThread appId:join-integration-test
    StreamsThread clientId:join-integration-test-1
    Active tasks:
        StreamsTask taskId:0_0
            ProcessorTopology:
            KSTREAM-SOURCE-0000000000: topics: [user-clicks] children [KSTREAM-LEFTJOIN-0000000003]
            KSTREAM-LEFTJOIN-0000000003: children [KSTREAM-MAP-0000000004]
            KSTREAM-MAP-0000000004: children [KSTREAM-FILTER-0000000007]
            KSTREAM-FILTER-0000000007: children [KSTREAM-SINK-0000000006]
            KSTREAM-SINK-0000000006: topic:join-integration-test-ClicksPerRegionUnwindowed-repartition
            KSTREAM-SOURCE-0000000001: topics: [user-regions] children [KTABLE-SOURCE-0000000002]
            KTABLE-SOURCE-0000000002: stateStores [user-regions-store-name] 
            Partitions [user-clicks-0,user-regions-0]
        StreamsTask taskId:1_0
            ProcessorTopology:
            KSTREAM-SOURCE-0000000008: topics: [ClicksPerRegionUnwindowed-repartition] children [KSTREAM-REDUCE-0000000005]
            KSTREAM-REDUCE-0000000005: stateStores [ClicksPerRegionUnwindowed] children [KTABLE-TOSTREAM-0000000009]
            KTABLE-TOSTREAM-0000000009: children [KSTREAM-SINK-0000000010]
            KSTREAM-SINK-0000000010: topic:output-topic
            Partitions [join-integration-test-ClicksPerRegionUnwindowed-repartition-0]
    Standby tasks:

```
@enothereska Looks good to me, thanks for the change. I confirmed it still runs and output is good.

Here's a link to system tests: http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2016-07-21--001.1469105780--hachikuji--KAFKA-3888--3ef8f80/report.html. I believe the failures are known problems, but I am investigating.
Overall LGTM - @miguno has some good suggestions for some of the Sysout messages.
Two more minor comments, otherwise LGTM.
@ijuma Ok I removed that line, thanks.
Merged to trunk. Thanks @enothereska for your patience!

@mjsax @miguno Some context about packaging: currently we have an `AdminClient` that uses `ZkUtils` under kafka-core mainly for topics manipulation etc, which I assume would be removed after KIP-4. According to @ijuma the new `AdminClient` will only depend on our protocol, so it should be in `kafka-clients` under `org.apache.kafka.*` (the actual package name is up for discussion, there are a few options).

In that case, maybe we should, in the very-near future, move this client from kafka-tools to kafka-streams as well in `trunk` once we remove the ZK dependency, while let it stay in `0.10.0` branch, and state in the upgrade docs that this class is moved. WDYT?
LGTM, merged to trunk.
Sounds ok to me.

@guozhangwang, one thing to consider is whether the new `AdminClient` will have all the functionality you need for this tool. It won't necessarily support everything supported by the existing one. Also, the existing one will probably continue to exist (the broker still needs to make the various changes to ZK), but we may want to rename it to avoid confusion (this hasn't been discussed much yet).
Minor comment, but otherwise LGTM.
